importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Paris Climate Agreement, which marked a pivotal shift in global climate policy and set a new trajectory for warming levels and superhot days.
The baseline period (1991–2020) used to define 'superhot days' and establish normal temperature comparisons for climate attribution.
The publication date of the study, indicating the most current assessment of climate change impacts on extreme heat events.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time horizon used in the study to project future increases in superhot days under different warming scenarios.

keyTakeAways: Climate change is causing an increase in dangerous 'superhot days' — days warmer than 90% of comparable days between 1991 and 2020.
The world is on track for 2.6°C of warming by 2100, resulting in 57 additional superhot days annually, half the increase from the pre-Paris 4°C scenario.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, the world was projected to see 114 extra superhot days per year due to 4°C warming.
Since 2015, the planet has already seen 11 additional superhot days on average.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face massive increases in heat exposure — Panama alone could see 149 extra superhot days.
These 10 nations collectively produce only 1% of global heat-trapping emissions, yet face the largest heat spikes.
In contrast, top carbon emitters like the U.S., China, and India — responsible for 42% of global CO2 — face only 23–30 extra superhot days.
The study reveals a profound global inequity in climate impacts, with low-emitting countries bearing the brunt of extreme heat.
Experts warn that this heat inequality could deepen global divisions and contribute to geopolitical instability.
Experts, including Friederike Otto and Andrew Weaver, emphasize that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by these extreme heat events.

namedEntities.name: World Weather Attribution
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that conducts climate attribution studies to link extreme weather events to climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This organization led the study analyzing the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific attribution of extreme heat events to global warming.

namedEntities.name: Climate Central
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based climate research organization focused on understanding and communicating climate risks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central partnered with World Weather Attribution to conduct the study, contributing to the credibility and reach of the findings.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement shifted the global warming trajectory from 4°C to 2.6°C by 2100, reducing projected superhot days from 114 to 57 annually.

namedEntities.name: Johan Rockstrom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert commentary on the study, emphasizing that even under current commitments, the future remains disastrous for billions of people.

namedEntities.name: Friederike Otto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Coauthor of the study and climate scientist at Imperial College London.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She contributed to the analysis and emphasized that heat-related deaths will affect tens of thousands or millions of people annually.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Weaver
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Climate scientist at the University of Victoria.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided independent expert commentary on the climate injustice revealed by the study, noting it could exacerbate global inequities and instability.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Panama is projected to face 149 additional superhot days annually, one of the top 10 nations affected by climate-related heat spikes.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is among the 10 nations facing the largest increases in dangerous heat days, highlighting the disproportionate climate impact on vulnerable small states.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small island nation in the South Pacific.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is included in the list of nations with the greatest increase in superhot days, illustrating the disproportionate burden of climate change on low-emitting countries.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The world's largest carbon emitter in terms of absolute emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Despite being responsible for a significant portion of global CO2 emissions, the U.S. faces only 23–30 extra superhot days, showing a disconnect between emissions and heat exposure.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gases in terms of total emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is projected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite contributing 42% of global CO2 emissions, highlighting a major climate injustice.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major global emitter of greenhouse gases with large population and rapid development.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: India is projected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite contributing significantly to global emissions, showing unequal climate impacts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current global commitments to reduce emissions, the world will still face 57 additional 'superhot days' annually by 2100 — defined as days warmer than 90% of comparable days between 1991 and 2020. This represents a significant reduction from the 114 extra days projected under a pre-Paris 4°C warming scenario. However, the study reveals a stark global inequity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa — which produce only 1% of global emissions — will face massive spikes in dangerous heat, while top carbon emitters such as the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts warn that this disparity could deepen global inequalities and fuel geopolitical instability, with tens of thousands or millions of people facing health risks from extreme heat annually.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
